qas.question: What do bathyctena chuni, euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera have in common?

answers.text: they produce secretions (ink) that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies

qas.question: When do bathyctena chuni, euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera  excrete secretions?
What are the secretions commonly called?
Do adults or juveniles secretions luminesce brighter?
What do Bathyctena chuni, Euplokamis stationis and Euhamphaea veilligera produce only when they change color?
Are most ctenophores the same or a different color?
What happens to ocean water when it absorbs certain wavelengths?
What does ocean water do to luminescence from certain animals?
What has been proven is released by ctenophores becaue of their environment?

context: When some species, including Bathyctena chuni, Euplokamis stationis and Eurhamphaea vexilligera, are disturbed, they produce secretions (ink) that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies. Juveniles will luminesce more brightly in relation to their body size than adults, whose luminescence is diffused over their bodies. Detailed statistical investigation has not suggested the function of ctenophores' bioluminescence nor produced any correlation between its exact color and any aspect of the animals' environments, such as depth or whether they live in coastal or mid-ocean waters.
